            By 
Nahal Toosi

09/24/15, 10:04 AM EDT
Pope Francis stood before a bitterly divided U.S. Congress on Thursday and reminded lawmakers of that most golden of rules, “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you.”
Those others, the pope made it clear, include immigrants, the impoverished, the Earth itself, and political rivals.
The speech, which combined words of faith with unmistakable political and policy requests, offered something for each of America’s two main political parties. But overall, with its much stronger emphasis on the environment and welcoming immigrants, and relatively brief and opaque references to stopping gay marriage and abortion, it is much more likely to cheer Democrats than Republican -- not a surprise given the left-leaning reputation of the hugely popular pontiff.
Francis, who is the first pope to ever address a joint meeting of Congress, invoked four figures from American history -- former President Abraham Lincoln; the late Martin Luther King Jr.; Catholic social justice leader Dorothy Day; and the Cistercian monk Thomas Merton -- to both praise the United States but also urge it to live up to its global challenges.
He warned against not just religious extremism but factionalism in general, saying the world “demands that we confront every form of polarization, which would divide it into two camps.” In calling for greater political cooperation, Francis also appeared to ever-so-subtly rebuke the U.S. campaign finance system, saying, “If politics must truly be at the service of the human person, it follows that it cannot be a slave to the economy and finance.”

Photo gallery

            By 
                    POLITICO Staff

The House chamber was packed with lawmakers and their guests, while outside, thousands of people gathered on the West Lawn of the Capitol to hear the 78-year-old Roman Catholic leader, who is on his first-ever trip to the United States. The enthusiastic reception he has received in political circles would have been unthinkable just decades ago when anti-Catholicism was much more common.
The Argentine-born Francis spoke in English, a language that he is not that familiar with, reading through spectacles from a prepared paper text. He wore his customary white robes and skullcap and enunciated every word carefully.
He devoted significant sections of his speech to the need to protect and respect migrants and asylum seekers, reminding his influential audience that they, too, are descended from immigrants who helped build America. Amid ongoing debates in Congress and on the 2016 presidential campaign trail about immigration -- a discussion that, thanks to Republican candidate Donald Trump, has prompted calls for a border wall and mass deportations -- Francis urged compassion for Latin Americans who head to the United States in search of greater opportunities.
“We must not be taken aback by their numbers but rather view them as persons, seeing their faces and listening to their stories, trying to respond as best we can to their situation,” he said. “We need to avoid a common temptation nowadays: to discard whatever proves troublesome.”
Francis also emphasized the need to battle climate change, another issue that has put Republicans and Democrats at loggerheads, saying he had “no doubt that the United States -- and this Congress -- have an important role to play” in averting “the most serious effects of the environmental deterioration caused by human activity.” But, as if responding to conservative critics who say Francis doesn’t understand the economics and technology involved, the pope made it clear he believes all necessary tools must be brought to bear to help protect the environment.

KGB File

            By 
Kate Bennett

Citing his recent encyclical on the environment, Francis said it was possible to put technology “at the service of another type of progress, one which is healthier, more human, more social, more integral.” He added, “I am confident that America’s outstanding academic and research institutions can make a vital contribution in the years ahead.”
The pope, who has criticized “trickle-down economics” and unbridled capitalism in the past -- only to be accused by Republicans and other conservatives of knowing nothing about Western capitalism because he grew up in Argentina -- acknowledged the tremendous progress the United States has made in lifting people out of poverty, noting “it goes without saying that part of this great effort is the creation and distribution of wealth,” and that “business is a noble vocation.” But he also encouraged his audience to “keep in mind all those people around us who are trapped in a cycle of poverty.”
In his discussion of the Golden Rule, Francis briefly alluded to abortion by mentioning “our responsibility to protect and defend human life at every stage of its development.” But from there, he quickly pivoted to his goal of abolishing the death penalty, “since every life is sacred.”
In describing the importance of promoting dialogue over war, Francis obliquely referenced the recent rapprochement between the U.S. and Cuba, which he helped broker but which has left many Republicans fuming. He then turned pivoted to the need to stop the arms trade, wondering, “Why are deadly weapons being sold to those who plan to inflict untold suffering on individuals and society? Sadly, the answer, as we all know, is simply for money: money that is drenched in blood, often innocent blood.”



            By 
Nahal Toosi

Francis spent much of the end of his speech discussing the importance of the family, using only veiled references to the growing legal and cultural acceptance of gay marriage as a cause of concern for him. But in discussing threats “from within and without,” he made it clear that he had broader concerns about the disintegration of the traditional family than just who is marrying who.
“At the risk of oversimplifying, we might say that we live in a culture which pressures young people not to start a family, because they lack possibilities for the future. Yet this same culture presents others with so many options that they too are dissuaded from starting a family,” the pope said.
Toward the end, he exhorted the U.S. to live up to its ideals that allow people to dream, defend liberty, help the oppressed and sow peace. “It is my desire that this spirit continue to develop and grow so that as many young people as possible can inherit and dwell in a land which has inspired so many people to dream,” he said, before ending with “God bless America!”
